bibl.title: Samuel Gowen and Donald Webster v. JH McGraw. Application for Writ.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

keywords.term: James Ludlow James Seavey JH McGraw Thomas Newland C.F. Hess

div1.ab: Territory of Washington Third Judicial District ss.
In the district court holding terms at Seattle in the county of King.
In the Matter of the Application of Samuel Gowen and Donald Webster for A Writ of Habeas Corpus Application for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
To the Hon. Roger S. Greene, Judge of the District Court of the Third Judicial District of Washington Territory.
div1.p: The petition of Samuel Gowen and Donald Webster respectfully shows: that the said Samuel Gowen and Donald Websterand each of them is unlawfully imprisoned, detained, confined and restrained of his liberty by J.H. McGraw, the Sheriff of King County in Washington Territory, at the said imprisionment, dention, confinement and constraint are illegal and that the illegality thereof consists in this: to wit: -- --

The cause or pretence of the said imprisonment, dentention, confinement and restraint is a certain commitment dated -- Jan 17th, 1883, issued by one, Thomas L. Newland, who is or pretends to be a justice of the peace in whatcom county, Territory of Washington, which commitment is in the words and figures following, to wit"

"Territory of Washington "Whatcom County SS. "To any constable and the keeper of the jail of said county: " Whereas Samuel Gowen and Donald Webster ahve been brought "this day before the undersigned one of the Justices of the Peace "In and ForSaid County, charged on hte oath of Charles F. Hesswith having "on th 15th day of January, 1883, in said county commited the offense "of sault on the person of Mrs. C.F. Hessand made improper roposals "to Mrs. C.F. Hess destroyed saloon bar fixtures, liquors and breaking windows belonging to C.F. Hess. Keeping saloon at Sterling in said county anf territory and in the progress of the trial of said charges it appearing to the said Justice that the said Samuel Gowen and Donald Websterhave been guilty of the offense of sault on the person of Mrs. C.F. Hessand made improper proposals to the said Mrs. C.F. Hessthe wife of Charles F. Hess, destroyed Daloon Bar Fixture, liquors and Breaking windows. The property belonging to 16th day of January, 1883, commited at the time and placs aforesaid: and whereas the said Donald Webster and Samuel Gowen Samuel Gowen and Donald Websterhave failed to give bail in the sum of two hundred dollars each for their appearance to answer at the next term of the district court, as required by me therefore on the name of the United States you are commanded to recieve the said Samuel Gowan and Donald Webster into your custody and into the said jail nad they there safely keep until they be discharged by due course of law, given under my hand ths this 17th day of January, 1883.
div1.ab:
|Signed|Thomas S. Newland."
Justice of the Peace of Mount Vernon, in and for Whatcom Co. Wash. "Ter
Which commitment and all the proceedings thereunder are void and illegal for the following reasons, to wit:
div1.p: First. Because the facts in the case and the testimony givenon the trial and examination of these applicatsdo not show any probable cause or ground whatsoeverto charge them with any charge crime or misdemeanor whatsoeverthere being an entire absence and want of such probable causethere being no testimony whatsoever - tending to charge there applicants with assualt or any other crime or misdemeanor whatsoever.

Second. Becayse the complaintmade against these aplicants and all the testimonyon the examination and trial do not showor pretend that any offense was commitedove which thesaid Justice did not have jurisdiction to thy determine and punish, and which would not have been sufficiently punishedby a fine not exceeding 100 dollars and costs.

Third. Because these applicants are and were not guilty of the misdemeanorcharged against them nor of any other crime or misdemeanor whatsoever. The said act of the said justice in comitting these applicantsas aforesaid being arbitrary and unjust and holly unwarrantted by the law or the facts.

Fourth. Because the complaint made and the prosecuting witness himself did not say nor pretend to say that any offense was committed which was beyond the jurisidiction of ofsaid Justice of the Peace to try, determine, sentence and punish which would n ot have been sufficiently punished a fine not exceeding 100 dollars with costs.

Wherefore your petitioners and applicants pray that a Writ of Habeas Corpus may be granteddirected to the said J.H. McGraw Sheriff aforesaid commanding him to have the bodies of the aforesaid Samuel Gowen and Donald Webster, before your honor at a time and place therein to be specified to do and recieve what shall then and there be considered by your honor concerning saidSamuel Gowen and Donald Webster together with the time and cause of his detentio n, and said writ and thatsaid Samuel Gowen and Donald Webster may be restored to their liberty.
div1.ab: dated -- Seattle Feby 24th, 1883 Donald Webster Samuel Gowen
Territory of Washington, County of King |SS.
div1.p: Samuel Gowen and Donald Websterbeing duly sworn on oath, each for himself says: that he has heard read the foregoing application and that he knows the contents ther of and believes the same to be true.
div1.ab: Subscribed and Sworn to before me this 24th day of Feburary, 1883.
J. Wood, Notarypublic in and for King County, Washington Territory.
No. 3181 In Re Samuel Gowen and Donald Webster Habeas Corpus Application for Writ Filed Feburary 24 188 James Seavey, Clerk. By James P Ludlow Deputy Clerk. Hall + Wood for applicants
